Bloody Good Time is what I consider one of my (albeit many) guilty pleasures. Do I recommend it? Well... sort of.

First and foremost, what all potential buyers need to realize is the game never really finished development, may as well be considered 'dead' in terms of the online play (though there are a few groups that do planned game nights), and is far from perfect.

That said, it can be a very enjoyable game to mess around with now and then, as it does have bots for singleplayer experiences. Is it the ultimate in difficult or varied gameplay? Absolutely not. Is it stunningly beautiful with some kind of mind blowing story? Hardly (though I'm quite partial to the graphical style). But CAN YOU HAVE FUN IN A UNIQUE ENVIRONMENT AND EXPERIENCE? YES.

I think most folks that bought BGT initially were expecting a much more expanded experience from the developer's previous game: The Ship. However, the development was prematurely ended. They had *no chance* to make this a game that would meet expectations, so complaints about that should be summarily tossed out in my opinion.

What the game DID end up providing was a framework that is fun to play, unique to experience, and a base of inspiration for future developers.

reviewText:
Bloody Good Time is a spiritual successor to The Ship. The best way to describe it is as a murder party FPS set at a movie shooting location. There are several game modes (Hunt, Elimination, Deathmatch...), but the goal is always the same in the end: kill the other actors. The player has a vast array of weapons (katana, revolver, exploding remote-controlled mouse, flamethrower...) and tools (gluegun, lullaby sheep...) to help him in this task. However, I think the game really shines when it is played against other human players rather than the AI and unluckily there is almost no one that still plays the game.

The game uses the Source engine, so it'll run on most computers. On the other hand, it isn't particularly good looking though the cartoon theme is well done and matches the game's athmosphere. As for the soundtrack, it is decent but forgetable.

TL;DR: Buy this game if you enjoyed the Ship and/or if you have friends to play it with. Its humor is greatly decreased when played against AI.

If you want to read a more thorough review, check out my blog post[gaming.jlcdk.com].

reviewText:
A pretty innovative game (although see also The Ship and a couple of others in the same ballpark) that has its flaws, but can be pretty fun once you get the hang of it all. Basically you play an actor that needs to kill the other actors in the movie so you can be the star.

Although there are a few game modes, the core is The Hunt - you have one opponent to kill, while someone else is tasked with killing you. So essentially you have a FPS version of Chompy Chomp Chomp and you rush about collecting weapons and items to help you, heading to where your target is on the minimap (or you get regular notifications when they move to a new area of the map), while trying to avoid traps and other people who might be out to kill you themselves.

The learning curve is pretty steep - you really need to know the maps intimately, including what each area is called, and what the quickest routes to get there from where you are is (there are usually dozens of routes as there are ladders, stairs, doors, corridors - pretty much every room/area has 4 or 5 ways out, and many have 10 or more. You also need to know where the weapons and traps are and how to use some of the more esoteric weapons like the rat bomb (and when to use it), and how to best use the bonus items which can be game changing when properly applied. Plus you need to know where all the traps are, and critically where they can be triggered from so that you know when it is safe to pass through. And then you need to track which weapons are currently good to use, as well as knowing the ins and outs of the different game modes, which will be switched every few minutes.

The weapons are not really balanced, but this is kind of as designed - this is mitigated somewhat by the scoring system - the good weapons usually get enough use they rarely ascend to a being a high scoring weapon after the first round, but in practise getting an easy kill for average score beats a strategy of trying to successfully use every awkward weapon in a cycle as they get to 5*. Another issue is the Blood Money round, which basically scores way to highly, such that most of the rest of the game often becomes a tie breaker between the people that did well in that one round.

Once you have the hang of it, and have some friends who also do, things finally click and you will probably start having a Bloody Good Time, but I can see plenty of people deciding that getting to that point isn't worth the payoff, as even then this game is quirky, flawed and not particular well balanced.

Bloody Good Time is a first person shooter that takes a new and irreverent approach to multiplayer mayhem by putting players on a Hollywood set, where they get to choose their thrill.

From a spring-break beach house, to a hotel, players will discover the merciless world of movie studios where anyone can star in a Hollywood blockbuster film as long as they are willing to kill for the role.

The game is set up for a max of eight players online or via LAN play, giving it a multiplayer experience like no other.

Gameplay
In the game, players can be as devious or ruthless as possible by killing other competitors in nasty and brutal ways. Players can use an arsenal of toon-esque weapons including guns, a frying pan and even an exploding remote-controlled rat to throw the movie set into true mayhem and chaos.

Players will be able to choose from a variety of stereotypical B-movie characters, such as the bikini beach babe, the creepy clown, the reject ninja girl or the super jock. Each character is unique enough to not feel as if they are all clones of each other.

Okay, good news and bad news time.

Bloody Good Time is a fun cheap cartoony multiplayer FPS that while lacking the intregue and tense hunting flair of The Ship (also made by these guys) and the Multiplayer in Assassin's Creed is a genuinely enjoyable game with enough flair and complexity to be worth your time and money.

Bad news. The Multiplayer is dead. Literally. There are no dedicated servers, no servers to even speak of actually. If you buy this game, you'll have to play with bots whom are slightly weird in their patterns and lack the complexity that other human players possess. You can still play with your friends though. There's no option (or at least I haven't found it yet) that allows for a selective mix.

If you don't mind playing with bots and don't feel like picking up The Ship or play Assassin's Creed's Multiplayer mode, here's your poor man (but still enjoyable) alternative.

Bloody Good Time is a first person shooter that takes a new and irreverent approach to multiplayer mayhem by putting players on a Hollywood set, where they get to choose their thrill.

From a spring-break beach house, to a hotel, players will discover the merciless world of movie studios where anyone can star in a Hollywood blockbuster film as long as they are willing to kill for the role.

The game is set up for a max of eight players online or via LAN play, giving it a multiplayer experience like no other.

Gameplay
In the game, players can be as devious or ruthless as possible by killing other competitors in nasty and brutal ways. Players can use an arsenal of toon-esque weapons including guns, a frying pan and even an exploding remote-controlled rat to throw the movie set into true mayhem and chaos.

Players will be able to choose from a variety of stereotypical B-movie characters, such as the bikini beach babe, the creepy clown, the reject ninja girl or the super jock. Each character is unique enough to not feel as if they are all clones of each other.

However I did think it offered only a limited amount of content, such as there are only 3 maps and 4 gamemodes available to play (Not counting the short version of the hunt). I love the star rated weapon system where every round you earn more or less stars by using a weapon with a higher or lower star rating to kill your enemy, these ratings change every round based on how many kills were made during the previous round with that particular weapon.\nWould definitley recommened this game as it can keep you occupied for hours on end. However the lack of content does make it boring after a while.

It's got potential, but ultimately turns into a sort of party novelty game".

Got a group of friends who just want to have fun and faff about in a comedic competitive bunch of oddity? Sure why not.

Ultimately it's got no staying power
date: though. This is the kind of game that would've thrived as a Blockbuster rental."
